revision.text:
'''Attachment and Health''' is psychological model which considers how [[attachment theory]] pertains to people’s preferences and expectations for the proximity of others when faced with stress, threat, danger or pain.<ref name="hunter&maunder2001">{{cite journal|last2=Maunder|first2=RG|date=2001|title=Using attachment theory to understand illness behavior|journal=General Hospital Psychiatry|volume=23|issue=4|pages=177–82|pmid=11543843|last1=Hunter|first1=JJ|doi=10.1016/s0163-8343(01)00141-4}}</ref> In 1982 the American Psychiatrist, [[Lawrence Kolb]], noticed that patients with chronic pain displayed behaviours with their healthcare providers akin to what children might display with an attachment figure, thus marking one of the first applications of attachment theory to physical health.<ref name="kolb1982">{{cite journal|last1=Kolb|first1=LC|title=Attachment behavior and pain complaints.|journal=Psychosomatics|date=April 1982|volume=23|issue=4|pages=413–25|pmid=7079441|doi=10.1016/s0033-3182(82)73404-8}}</ref> Development of adult attachment theory and adult [[attachment measures]] in the 1990s provided researchers with the means to apply attachment theory to health in a more systematic way.<ref name="ravitz2010">{{cite journal|last1=Ravitz|first1=P|last2=Maunder|first2=R|last3=Hunter|first3=J|last4=Sthankiya|first4=B|last5=Lancee|first5=W|title=Adult attachment measures: a 25-year review|journal=Journal of Psychosomatic Research|date=October 2010|volume=69|issue=4|pages=419–32|pmid=20846544|doi=10.1016/j.jpsychores.2009.08.006}}</ref> Since that time it has been used to understand variation in stress response, health outcomes and health behaviour. Ultimately, the application of attachment theory to health care may enable health care practitioners to provide more personalized medicine by creating a deeper understanding of patient distress and allowing clinicians to better meet their needs and expectations.
==History of Attachment Theory== {{main|History of attachment theory}} {{see also|Attachment Theory}}
===Infant attachment=== [[John Bowlby]] and [[Mary Ainsworth]] developed attachment theory in the 1960s while investigating the effects of [[Maternal deprivation|maternal separation]] on infant development.<ref name="bretherton1992">{{cite journal|last1=Bretherton|first1=Inge|title=The origins of attachment theory: John Bowlby and Mary Ainsworth.|journal=Developmental Psychology|date=1992|volume=28|issue=5|pages=759–775|doi=10.1037/0012-1649.28.5.759}}</ref> The development of the [[Strange Situation]] task in 1965 by Ainsworth and Wittig allowed researchers to systematically investigate the attachment system operating between children and their parents.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mary|first1=Ainsworth|title=Patterns of attachment : a psychological study of the strange situation|date=1978|publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum Associates|location=Hillsdale, N.J.|isbn=978-0-89859-461-4}}</ref> The Strange Situation involves separating infant-parent dyads and observing infant behaviours upon reunion. Infant behaviour tended to follow patterns, leading to the development of three attachment categories: Secure, Anxious-Avoidant, and Anxious-Resistant. In 1990, Ainsworth added a new category, championed by [[Mary Main]], called Disorganized/Disoriented attachment, characterized by its less reliable pattern of behaviour.<ref>Main, M., & Solomon, J. (1986). Discovery of a new, insecure-disorganized/disoriented attachment pattern. In M. Yogman & T. B. Brazelton (Eds.), Affective development in infancy (pp. 95–124). Norwood, NJ: Ablex.</ref>
Bowlby believed attachment to be a primary biological drive to achieve proximity with a caregiver that transforms across child development to also encompass a psychological drive to find security by achieving a preferred interpersonal distance with an important caregiver he called an attachment figure.<ref name="bretherton1992" /> Insecure attachment patterns develop when caregivers are experienced as inconsistent or unpredictable, which necessitates the development of different strategies to achieve a sense of comfort and safety within an interpersonal setting. Furthermore, he posited that attachment figures function as a ''secure base'' that facilitate environmental eexploration and that ''attachment behaviours'' are triggered by perceived stress, danger or pain, and are thus ''state dependent''.<ref name="fonagy2001">{{cite book|title=Attachment and Psychoanalysis|date=2001|publisher=Other Press|last1=Fonagy|first1=P}}</ref>
===Adult attachment=== {{main|Attachment in adults}}
In the late 1980s Cindy Hazan and Phillip Shaver applied attachment theory to adult romantic relationships based on observations of the interactions between adult romantic partners.☃☃ They noticed that romantic partners often prefer to be physically close, become anxious when they are separated and that stressful situations can be buffered by the presence of a romantic partner. Three main methods of measuring adult attachment have been developed (see [[attachment measures]]), with slightly different purposes and variable amounts of concordance between them.<ref name= eagle2013 /> Some aim to categorize attachment style while others rate degrees of attachment anxiety and avoidance.
==Attachment Styles== Attachment styles refer to characteristic patterns of thought concerning the ability of self and others to help an individual achieve security. Longitudinal studies have suggested attachment is fairly stable from childhood to adulthood.<ref name="Weinfield2000">{{cite journal|last2=Sroufe|first2=LA|last3=Egeland|first3=B|date=2000|title=Attachment from infancy to early adulthood in a high-risk sample: continuity, discontinuity, and their correlates.|journal=Child Development|volume=71|issue=3|pages=695–702|pmid=10953936|last1=Weinfield|first1=NS|doi=10.1111/1467-8624.00178}}</ref><ref name="waters2000">{{cite journal|last2=Merrick|first2=S|last3=Treboux|first3=D|last4=Crowell|first4=J|last5=Albersheim|first5=L|date=2000|title=Attachment security in infancy and early adulthood: a twenty-year longitudinal study|journal=Child Development|volume=71|issue=3|pages=684–9|pmid=10953934|last1=Waters|first1=E|doi=10.1111/1467-8624.00176|citeseerx=10.1.1.541.384}}</ref> When shifts do occur it is usually with good reason, with shifts away from secure attachment due to increased hardship and shifts towards secure related to finding partners in adulthood or finding symbolic attachments (God, places, pets) <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Segal|first1=DL|last2=Needham|first2=TN|last3=Coolidge|first3=FL|title=Age differences in attachment orientations among younger and older adults: evidence from two self-report measures of attachment|journal=International Journal of Aging & Human Development|date=2009|volume=69|issue=2|pages=119–32|pmid=19960862|doi=10.2190/ag.69.2.c|citeseerx=10.1.1.472.7765}}</ref>
===Secure=== Securely attached people generally have positive views about themselves and about others. They tend to agree with statements "It is relatively easy for me to become emotionally close to others. I am comfortable depending on others and having others depend on me. I don't worry about being alone or others not accepting me."<ref name="bartholomew&horowitz1991">{{cite journal|last2=Horowitz|first2=LM|date=August 1991|title=Attachment styles among young adults: a test of a four-category model.|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=61|issue=2|pages=226–44|pmid=1920064|last1=Bartholomew|first1=K|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.61.2.226}}</ref>
===Insecure=== '''Anxious-preoccupied''' people tend to view themselves less positively than okthey view others. They are more likely to become highly anxious when they are away from their attachment partners and are at risk of becoming, or seeming, dependent. They tend to agree with statements such as “I want to be completely emotionally intimate with others, but I often find that others are reluctant to get as close as I would like", and "I am uncomfortable being without close relationships, but I sometimes worry that others don't value me as much as I value them." <ref name="bartholomew&horowitz1991" />
'''Avoidant-dismissive''' people tend to have a positive view of themselves and a less positive view of others. They often highly value independence and become uncomfortable in, or resist, situations where they become dependent on others. They tend to agree with statements such as "I am comfortable without close emotional relationships", "It is very important to me to feel independent and self-sufficient", and "I prefer not to depend on others or have others depend on me." This is considered to be roughly equivalent to the anxious-avoidant style in children.<ref name="bartholomew&horowitz1991" />
'''Fearful-avoidant''' people tend to have conflicted, and often negative, views of themselves and of others. They often desire to have emotional relationships but feel uncomfortable when others get too close. They tend to agree with statements such as "I am somewhat uncomfortable getting close to others. I want emotionally close relationships, but I find it difficult to trust others completely, or to depend on them. I sometimes worry that I will be hurt if I allow myself to become too close to others."<ref name="bartholomew&horowitz1991" /> People with loss or trauma in childhood are at greater risk of developing this style of attachment.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Byun|first1=S|last2=Brumariu|first2=LE|last3=Lyons-Ruth|first3=K|title=Disorganized Attachment in Young Adulthood as Partial Mediator of Relations Between Severity of Childhood Abuse and Dissociation |journal=Journal of Trauma & Dissociation|date=2 February 2016|pmid=26836233|pmc=5004628|doi=10.1080/15299732.2016.1141149|volume=17|issue=4|pages=460–79}}</ref>
===Insecure Attachment Styles in Healthcare Settings===
'''Anxious-Preoccupied''' People with anxious-preoccupied attachment tend to be hypervigilant to signs of danger and to worry or catastrophize about symptoms. In health care appointments, their narrative is full of intense negative emotion but relatively sparse in the specific detail desired by health care providers. This presentation can readily be perceived as “needy” or “dramatic”. If the healthcare provider pulls away in response it may reinforce the patient’s need to articulate their distress, creating a cycle of distress-withdrawal-distress.<ref name="maunder&hunter2015">{{cite book|last1=Maunder|first1=R|last2=Hunter|first2=J|title=Love, Fear and Health: How our attachments to others shape health and health care|publisher=University of Toronto Press|location=Toronto}}</ref><ref name="hunter&maunder2015">{{cite book|last1=Hunter|first1=J|last2=Maunder|first2=R|title=Improving Patient Treatment with Attachment Theory: a guide for primary care providers and specialists|date=2015|publisher=Springer}}</ref>
'''Avoidant-Dismissive''' People with avoidant dismissive attachment emphasizetheir independence and minimizing expressing distress. They may delay seeking healthcare (see healthcare utilization), minimize reporting symptoms and disclose limited personal information.<ref name="maunder&hunter2015" /><ref name="hunter&maunder2015" />
'''Fearful-Disorganized''' People with fearful attachment often avoid routine healthcare, but present in a crisis with volatile, intense, negative emotions. Due to their degree of distress, they can present a disorganized narrative that is difficult for providers to follow and interpret diagnostically.<ref name="maunder&hunter2015" /><ref name="hunter&maunder2015" />
==Working Model== Working models are representatives of the cognitive [[Schema (psychology)|schema]], or psychological structure (often unconscious), which underlie the different attachment classifications.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zimmermann|first1=P|title=Structure and functions of internal working models of attachment and their role for emotion regulation|journal=Attachment & Human Development|date=December 1999|volume=1|issue=3|pages=291–306|pmid=11708228|doi=10.1080/14616739900134161}}</ref> Working models develop in children over time based on their experiences with their attachment figures. The cognitive schema for attachment consists of views of the efficacy of self and other to create security in times of distress.
===Bartholomew and Horowitz Model=== Bartholomew and Horowitz proposed and verified a working model based on two dimensions; the view of the self (self-esteem) and the view of others (sociability)<ref name="bartholomew&horowitz1991" /> *Secure- Positive view of self, Positive view of other *Dismissive- Positive view of self, Negative view of other *Preoccupied- Negative view of self, Positive view of other *Fearful- Negative view of self, Negative view of other
===Prototype-Insecurity Classification Model=== In 2012 Maunder and Hunter<ref name="maunder&hunter2012">{{cite journal|last1=Maunder|first1=RG|last2=Hunter|first2=JJ|title=A prototype-based model of adult attachment for clinicians|journal=Psychodynamic Psychiatry|date=December 2012|volume=40|issue=4|pages=549–73|pmid=23216396|doi=10.1521/pdps.2012.40.4.549}}</ref> combined the internal working model with the attitudes, behaviours and emotional expression of the different styles to create a prototype based classification that included severity of insecurity. This model was designed to be clinically useful, allowing healthcare providers to identify and predict the behaviours of patients whose attachment systems were activated by pain and illness.
They distinguish the different attachment styles by; 1) attachment anxiety, the discomfort someone feels when separated, 2) attachment avoidance, which is discomfort associated with closeness and 3) severity of insecurity *Secure- Low anxiety, low avoidance, low severity of insecurity *Dismissive- Low anxiety, high avoidance, moderate insecurity *Preoccupied- High anxiety, low avoidance, moderate insecurity *Fearful- High anxiety, high avoidance, high insecurity *Disorganized- High anxiety, high avoidance, high insecurity. The difference between disorganized and fearful is that people with disorganized attachment do not use a consistent strategy to find security.
==Attachment and health outcomes== Attachment and health interact on multiple levels. Attachment is a biologically based system tied to our response to distress and attachment styles appear to confer differences in stress physiology. Illness and pain themselves act as an “activating signal” for attachment systems, and health care providers act as attachment figures in their role addressing illness and pain. Accordingly, attachment styles influence patient perception of illness, health care utilization, medication compliance and treatment response.<ref name="hunter&maunder2001" /><ref name="feeney2000">{{cite journal|last1=Feeney|first1=J A|title=Implications of attachment style for patterns of health and illness|journal=Child: Care, Health and Development|date=July 2000|volume=26|issue=4|pages=277–288|doi=10.1046/j.1365-2214.2000.00146.x}}</ref>
===Physical health=== While strong social support has been linked to greater resilience to stress and lower medical morbidity and mortality, the mechanism behind this association is poorly understood.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ozbay|first1=F|last2=Fitterling|first2=H|last3=Charney|first3=D|last4=Southwick|first4=S|title=Social support and resilience to stress across the life span: a neurobiologic framework|journal=Current Psychiatry Reports|date=August 2008|volume=10|issue=4|pages=304–10|pmid=18627668|doi=10.1007/s11920-008-0049-7}}</ref> In the late 1990s, Paul Ciechanowski investigated the role of attachment styles in patients managing diabetes, finding that individuals with an avoidant-dismissive style were less likely to be compliant with treatment recommendations and had less well-controlled disease as measured by glycosylated hemoglobin.<ref name="ciechanowski2004">{{cite journal|last2=Russo|first2=J|last3=Katon|first3=W|last4=Von Korff|first4=M|last5=Ludman|first5=E|last6=Lin|first6=E|last7=Simon|first7=G|last8=Bush|first8=T|date=2004|title=Influence of patient attachment style on self-care and outcomes in diabetes|journal=Psychosomatic Medicinevolume=66|issue=5|pages=720–8|pmid=15385697|last1=Ciechanowski|first1=P|doi=10.1097/01.psy.0000138125.59122.23|volume=66}}</ref> Larger scale evidence comes from a large American survey of self-reported attachment styles and physical illness conducted by McWilliams and Bailey.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McWilliams|first=Lachlan A.|last2=Bailey|first2=S. Jeffrey|date=2010-07-01|title=Associations between adult attachment ratings and health conditions: evidence from the National Comorbidity Survey Replication|pmid=20658833|journal=Health Psychology: Official Journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association|volume=29|issue=4|pages=446–453|doi=10.1037/a0020061|issn=1930-7810}}</ref> They found that those with insecure attachment reported more physical illness than securely attached individuals. Specifically, they found preoccupied individuals reported more heart disease, and dismissive individuals more pain conditions. A prospective study followed children until the age of 32 and found a similar pattern of results. They found that people with anxious-resistant (dismissive) styles of attachment reported vague, non-specific symptoms more often, and those with anxious-preoccupied classification had a higher rate of inflammation-based illnesses. This prospective study was particularly important because of the difficulty assigning causation in the often observed relationship between chronic pain and insecure attachment.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Davies|first=K. A.|last2=Macfarlane|first2=G. J.|last3=McBeth|first3=J.|last4=Morriss|first4=R.|last5=Dickens|first5=C.|date=2009-06-01|title=Insecure attachment style is associated with chronic widespread pain|pmid=19345016|journal=Pain|volume=143|issue=3|pages=200–205|doi=10.1016/j.pain.2009.02.013|issn=1872-6623|pmc=2806947}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kowal|first=John|last2=McWilliams|first2=Lachlan A.|last3=Péloquin|first3=Katherine|last4=Wilson|first4=Keith G.|last5=Henderson|first5=Peter R.|last6=Fergusson|first6=Dean A.|date=2015-06-01|title=Attachment insecurity predicts responses to an interdisciplinary chronic pain rehabilitation program|pmid=25716120|journal=Journal of Behavioral Medicine|volume=38|issue=3|pages=518–526|doi=10.1007/s10865-015-9623-8|issn=1573-3521}}</ref> Further support is derived from experimental pain studies that have demonstrated numerous risk factors for the development of a chronic pain disorder associated with insecure adult attachment including lower perceived control of pain, higher pain catastrophizing and higher perceived pain intensity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Meredith|first=Pamela J.|last2=Strong|first2=Jenny|last3=Feeney|first3=Judith A.|date=2005-01-01|title=Evidence of a relationship between adult attachment variables and appraisals of chronic pain|pmid=16341306|journal=Pain Research & Management|volume=10|issue=4|pages=191–200|issn=1203-6765|doi=10.1155/2005/745650}}</ref>
===Mental health=== Attachment theory can be conceptualized as a theory of emotional regulation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Waters|first=Sara F.|last2=Virmani|first2=Elita A.|last3=Thompson|first3=Ross A.|last4=Meyer|first4=Sara|last5=Raikes|first5=H. Abigail|last6=Jochem|first6=Rachel|date=2009-09-23|title=Emotion Regulation and Attachment: Unpacking Two Constructs and Their Association|journal=Journal of Psychopathology and Behavioral Assessment|language=en|volume=32|issue=1|pages=37–47|doi=10.1007/s10862-009-9163-z|issn=0882-2689|pmc=2821505|pmid=20174446}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mikulincer|first=Mario|last2=Shaver|first2=Phillip R.|last3=Pereg|first3=Dana|title=Attachment Theory and Affect Regulation: The Dynamics, Development, and Cognitive Consequences of Attachment-Related Strategies|journal=Motivation and Emotion|language=en|volume=27|issue=2|pages=77–102|doi=10.1023/A:1024515519160|issn=0146-7239|year=2003}}</ref> Bowlby predicted that insecure attachment would be a risk factor for mental health difficulties based on ineffective, or overly rigid, strategies for reducing distress and maintaining psychological resilience.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sroufe|first=L. A.|last2=Carlson|first2=E. A.|last3=Levy|first3=A. K.|last4=Egeland|first4=B.|date=1999-01-01|title=Implications of attachment theory for developmental psychopathology|pmid=10208353|journal=Development and Psychopathology|volume=11|issue=1|pages=1–13|issn=0954-5794|doi=10.1017/s0954579499001923}}</ref> There is a substantial body of literature that supports an association between adult insecure attachment and a wide variety of mental health disorders including depression, anxiety, eating, psychotic and personality disorders. Prospective evidence (research starting with infant attachment and following up over time) is mostly limited to studies following infants into childhood or adolescence as opposed to adulthood, but does demonstrate that insecure attachment is a general risk factor for both internalizing and externalizing symptomatology.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fearon|first1=R. Pasco|last2=Bakermans-Kranenburg|first2=Marian J.|last3=van IJzendoorn|first3=Marinus H.|last4=Lapsley|first4=Anne-Marie|last5=Roisman|first5=Glenn I.|title=The Significance of Insecure Attachment and Disorganization in the Development of Children's Externalizing Behavior: A Meta-Analytic Study|journal=Child Development|date=March 2010|volume=81|issue=2|pages=435–456|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8624.2009.01405.x|pmid=20438450}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Groh|first1=Ashley M.|last2=Roisman|first2=Glenn I.|last3=van IJzendoorn|first3=Marinus H.|last4=Bakermans-Kranenburg|first4=Marian J.|last5=Fearon|first5=R. Pasco|title=The Significance of Insecure and Disorganized Attachment for Children's Internalizing Symptoms: A Meta-Analytic Study|journal=Child Development|date=January 2012|doi=10.1111/j.1467-8624.2011.01711.x|pmid=22235928|volume=83|issue=2|pages=591–610}}</ref> Of the handful of studies that have followed infants to adulthood, the only two clear relationships that exist are between (1) disorganized attachment and dissociative symptoms and (2) resistant attachment and anxiety disorders in late adolescence.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cassidy|first1=J.|last2=Shaver|first2=P.R.|title=Handbook of attachment: Theory, research, and clinical applications|date=2008|publisher=Guilford|pages=718–744}}</ref>
Causal relationships between insecure attachment and mental illness may be complex.<ref name="fonagy2001" /><ref name="eagle2013" /><ref name="hunter&maunder2015" /> Some risk factors for insecure attachment such as loss of parental figure, and sexual or physical abuse, are also risk factors for mental health disorders.<ref name="eagle2013" >{{cite book|last1=Eagle|first1=M.|title=Attachment and Psychoanalysis: Theory, research and clinical|date=2013|publisher=Guilford|location=New York}}</ref> Self-report measures of attachment may be biased by mental health conditions. For example, clinical depression is often associated with negative thoughts about the self, and this cognitive bias may influence the self-report in attachment questionnaires. There may be interpersonal consequences from untreated mental health conditions. Pre-existing psychological problems can increase the likelihood of secure attachment changing to insecure attachment over time.<ref name="mikulincer&shaver2012">{{cite journal|last2=Shaver|first2=PR|date=February 2012|title=An attachment perspective on psychopathology|journal=World Psychiatry : Official Journal of the World Psychiatric Association (WPA)|volume=11|issue=1|pages=11–5|pmid=22294997|last1=Mikulincer|first1=M|doi=10.1016/j.wpsyc.2012.01.003|pmc=3266769}}</ref>
==Mechanisms by which Attachment Influences Health== Maunder and Hunter outline 3 ways in which insecure attachment can serve as a risk factor for health problems: 1) it may increase one’s susceptibility to stress by changing stress physiology, 2) it may be related to potentially harmful behaviours undertaken to regulate affect, and 3) it may change the way people interact with the healthcare system.<ref name="hunter&maunder2001" />
===Attachment and Stress=== See also: [[stress (biology)]], [[stress (psychological)]] The stress response in humans is largely governed by the [[hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis]] (HPA) and [[sympathetic nervous system]]. The HPA axis has garnered particular attention from attachment researchers because it is known to be activated by social stressors.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Diamond|first1=Lisa M.|title=Contributions of Psychophysiology to Research on Adult Attachment: Review and Recommendations|journal=Personality and Social Psychology Review|date=November 2001|volume=5|issue=4|pages=276–295|doi=10.1207/S15327957PSPR0504_1|citeseerx=10.1.1.327.2676}}</ref> The normal response for this system is to release stress hormones, particularly cortisol, for a brief duration and then shut itself off due to negative feedback, resulting in a short, strong release of cortisol. The HPA axis also follows a [[circadian rhythm]], with highest release within about 30 minutes to 1 hour upon awakening, called the cortisol response to awakening (CRA), and a slow taper throughout the day. Researchers have looked at both cortisol response to stress (CRS) and CRA to determine if attachment anxiety and avoidance underlie individual differences in HPA activity.
Findings in the field have inconsistent. The evidence suggests that (a) individuals with high attachment anxiety perceive a higher degree of distress when faced with a stressor and have higher baseline anxiety compared to those low in attachment anxiety,<ref name="ditzen2008">{{cite journal|last1=Ditzen|first1=B|last2=Schmidt|first2=S|last3=Strauss|first3=B|last4=Nater|first4=UM|last5=Ehlert|first5=U|last6=Heinrichs|first6=M|title=Adult attachment and social support interact to reduce psychological but not cortisol responses to stress|journal=Journal of Psychosomatic Research|date=May 2008|volume=64|issue=5|pages=479–86|pmid=18440400|doi=10.1016/j.jpsychores.2007.11.011}}</ref><ref name="maunder2006">{{cite journal|last1=Maunder|first1=Robert G.|last2=Lancee|first2=William J.|last3=Nolan|first3=Robert P.|last4=Hunter|first4=Jonathan J.|last5=Tannenbaum|first5=David W.|title=The relationship of attachment insecurity to subjective stress and autonomic function during standardized acute stress in healthy adults|journal=Journal of Psychosomatic Research|date=March 2006|volume=60|issue=3|pages=283–290|doi=10.1016/j.jpsychores.2005.08.013|pmid=16516661}}</ref><ref name="kidd2013">{{cite journal|last1=Kidd|first1=Tara|last2=Hamer|first2=Mark|last3=Steptoe|first3=Andrew|title=Adult attachment style and cortisol responses across the day in older adults|journal=Psychophysiology|date=September 2013|volume=50|issue=9|pages=841–847|doi=10.1111/psyp.12075|pmid=23808770|pmc=4298031}}</ref><ref name="dewitte2010">{{cite journal|last1=Dewitte|first1=Marieke|last2=De Houwer|first2=Jan|last3=Goubert|first3=Liesbet|last4=Buysse|first4=Ann|title=A multi-modal approach to the study of attachment-related distress|journal=Biological Psychology|date=September 2010|volume=85|issue=1|pages=149–162|doi=10.1016/j.biopsycho.2010.06.006|pmid=20600574|url=https://biblio.ugent.be/publication/1091912|format=Submitted manuscript}}</ref> (b) most studies suggest higher cortisol reactivity to stress in anxiously attached individuals,<ref name="dewitte2010" /><ref name="powers2006">{{cite journal|last1=Powers|first1=SI|last2=Pietromonaco|first2=PR|last3=Gunlicks|first3=M|last4=Sayer|first4=A|title=Dating couples' attachment styles and patterns of cortisol reactivity and recovery in response to a relationship conflict.|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|date=April 2006|volume=90|issue=4|pages=613–28|pmid=16649858|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.90.4.613}}</ref><ref name="quirin2008">{{cite journal|last1=Quirin|first1=M|last2=Pruessner|first2=JC|last3=Kuhl|first3=J|title=HPA system regulation and adult attachment anxiety: individual differences in reactive and awakening cortisol.|journal=Psychoneuroendocrinology|date=June 2008|volume=33|issue=5|pages=581–90|pmid=18329180|doi=10.1016/j.psyneuen.2008.01.013}}</ref><ref name="laurent2007">{{cite journal|last1=Laurent|first1=Heidemarie|last2=Powers|first2=Sally|title=Emotion regulation in emerging adult couples: Temperament, attachment, and HPA response to conflict|journal=Biological Psychology|date=September 2007|volume=76|issue=1–2|pages=61–71|doi=10.1016/j.biopsycho.2007.06.002|pmid=17681662|pmc=2041804}}</ref><ref name="kidd2011">{{cite journal|last1=Kidd|first1=Tara|last2=Hamer|first2=Mark|last3=Steptoe|first3=Andrew|title=Examining the association between adult attachment style and cortisol responses to acute stress|journal=Psychoneuroendocrinology|date=July 2011|volume=36|issue=6|pages=771–779|doi=10.1016/j.psyneuen.2010.10.014|pmid=21106296|pmc=3114075}}</ref><ref name="smyth2015">{{cite journal|last1=Smyth|first1=Nina|last2=Thorn|first2=Lisa|last3=Oskis|first3=Andrea|last4=Hucklebridge|first4=Frank|last5=Evans|first5=Phil|last6=Clow|first6=Angela|title=Anxious attachment style predicts an enhanced cortisol response to group psychosocial stress|journal=Stress|date=11 March 2015|volume=18|issue=2|pages=143–148|doi=10.3109/10253890.2015.1021676|pmid=25758939}}</ref> while two studies did not support this trend<ref name="ditzen2008" /><ref name="smeets2010">{{cite journal|last1=Smeets|first1=T|title=Autonomic and hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal stress resilience: Impact of cardiac vagal tone.|journal=Biological Psychology|date=May 2010|volume=84|issue=2|pages=290–5|pmid=20206227|doi=10.1016/j.biopsycho.2010.02.015}}</ref>(c) avoidant-dismissive attachment has been less consistent, with some studies showing an increase in cortisol produced in response to a stressor,<ref name="powers2006" /><ref name="rifkin2008">{{cite journal|last1=Rifkin-Graboi|first1=A|title=Attachment status and salivary cortisol in a normal day and during simulated interpersonal stress in young men.|journal=Stress (Amsterdam, Netherlands)|date=May 2008|volume=11|issue=3|pages=210–24|pmid=18465468|doi=10.1080/10253890701706670}}</ref> and others not finding any differences in comparison to securely attached individuals<ref name="kidd2011" /><ref name="smyth2015" />(d) fearful attachment is associated with lower cortisol both upon awakening and in response to a stressor<ref name="kidd2013" /><ref name="kidd2011" /> although one study in pregnant women found less diurnal variation in those fearfully versus securely attached, leading to a higher bedtime cortisol level in the fearful group.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Costa-Martins|first1=José Manuel|last2=Moura-Ramos|first2=Mariana|last3=Cascais|first3=Maria João|last4=da Silva|first4=Carlos Fernandes|last5=Costa-Martins|first5=Henriqueta|last6=Pereira|first6=Marco|last7=Coelho|first7=Rui|last8=Tavares|first8=Jorge|title=Adult attachment style and cortisol responses in women in late pregnancy|journal=BMC Psychology|date=11 January 2016|volume=4|issue=1|pages=1|doi=10.1186/s40359-016-0105-8|pmid=26754482|pmc=4709978}}</ref> The finding that those with fearful attachment would show small cortisol reactivity in response to a stressor may seem counterintuitive but is in line with the predictions of stress researcher [[Bruce McEwen]], who hypothesized that frequent early stressors in life would cause an initial hyper-reactivity in the HPA axis that would over time become pathologically sluggish as the individual ages, leading to greater overall cortisol release and less adaptive responsivity.<ref name="mcewen2000">{{cite journal|last1=McEwen|first1=BS|title=Allostasis and allostatic load: implications for neuropsychopharmacology.|journal=Neuropsychopharmacology|date=February 2000|volume=22|issue=2|pages=108–24|pmid=10649824|doi=10.1016/s0893-133x(99)00129-3}}</ref>
Another related biological system that regulates stress response is the [[autonomic nervous system]]. In general, the sympathetic system is activated during times of stress and the parasympathetic system acts to decrease physical readiness for stress. These systems are sometimes called the “fight-or-flight” and “rest-or-digest” systems, respectively, and operate in a balance, as opposed to being totally on or off. Researchers can approximate the relative balance by looking at skin conductance, blood pressure and heart rate. Studies of this kind provided hard evidence that avoidant infants were truly distressed during the strange situation task<ref name="gander2015">{{cite journal|last1=Gander|first1=Manuela|last2=Buchheim|first2=Anna|title=Attachment classification, psychophysiology and frontal EEG asymmetry across the lifespan: a review|journal=Frontiers in Human Neuroscience|date=19 February 2015|volume=9|pages=79|doi=10.3389/fnhum.2015.00079|pmid=25745393|pmc=4333768}}</ref> despite their minimally distressed appearance as they showed elevations in heart rate when caregivers were away and took longer to return to baseline when the caregiver returned in comparison to securely attached infants. Studies of skin conductance and heart rate in adults have shown that those with avoidant attachment and anxious attachment will show markers of increased distress during attachment and non-attachment stressors compared to those securely attached.<ref name="maunder2006" /><ref name="gander2015" />
===Health behaviours=== According to attachment theory people with insecure attachment have less effective strategies for dealing with negative emotions compared to people with secure attachment. One way in which insecurely individuals may try to regulate their distress is by using strategies or behaviours that are attractive for their short term relief but may have deleterious risks over years like eating, drug use or risky sex. In a survey of 356 primary care patients in Toronto, rates of smoking, harmful drinking and obesity, were all found to be highest in those with the most severe anxious and avoidant attachment.<ref name="hunter&maunder2015" /> Both attachment anxiety and attachment avoidance have been linked in separate studies to increasing the risk of eating disorders and substance use in adolescents.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=O'Kearney|first1=R|title=Attachment disruption in anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa: a review of theory and empirical research.|journal=The International Journal of Eating Disorders|date=September 1996|volume=20|issue=2|pages=115–27|pmid=8863063|doi=10.1002/(sici)1098-108x(199609)20:2<115::aid-eat1>3.0.co;2-j}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Schindler|first1=Andreas|last2=Bröning|first2=Sonja|title=A Review on Attachment and Adolescent Substance Abuse: Empirical Evidence and Implications for Prevention and Treatment|journal=Substance Abuse|date=25 November 2014|volume=36|issue=3|pages=304–313|doi=10.1080/08897077.2014.983586|pmid=25424652}}</ref>
'''Eating''' A review of attachment and eating disorder literature in 2010 showed rates of insecure attachment to be approximately 70% in eating disorder populations in contrast to the 30-40% prevalence in the normal population.<ref name="zachrisson2010">{{cite journal|last1=Zachrisson|first1=HD|last2=Skårderud|first2=F|title=Feelings of insecurity: review of attachment and eating disorders.|journal=European Eating Disorders Review|date=March 2010|volume=18|issue=2|pages=97–106|pmid=20148392|doi=10.1002/erv.999}}</ref> These rates are similar to those found in other mental health populations.<ref name="bakermans2009">{{cite journal|last1=Bakermans-Kranenburg|first1=Marian J.|last2=van IJzendoorn|first2=Marinus H.|title=The first 10,000 Adult Attachment Interviews: distributions of adult attachment representations in clinical and non-clinical groups|journal=Attachment & Human Development|date=May 2009|volume=11|issue=3|pages=223–263|doi=10.1080/14616730902814762|pmid=19455453}}</ref> The review noted small trends for anxious attachment to be more highly associated with binge-purging symptomatology and avoidant attachment to be more highly associated with restrictive.<ref name="zachrisson2010" /> The relationship between high attachment anxiety and disinhibited eating, or binge eating, has also been found in non-clinical<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Han|first1=Suejung|last2=Pistole|first2=M. Carole|title=College Student Binge Eating: Insecure Attachment and Emotion Regulation|journal=Journal of College Student Development|date=2014|volume=55|issue=1|pages=16–29|doi=10.1353/csd.2014.0004}}</ref><ref name="wilkinson2010">{{cite journal|last1=Wilkinson|first1=L L|last2=Rowe|first2=A C|last3=Bishop|first3=R J|last4=Brunstrom|first4=J M|title=Attachment anxiety, disinhibited eating, and body mass index in adulthood|journal=International Journal of Obesity|date=30 March 2010|volume=34|issue=9|pages=1442–1445|doi=10.1038/ijo.2010.72|pmid=20351734}}</ref> and pre-bariatric surgery populations.<ref name="shakory2015">{{cite journal|last1=Shakory|first1=Sharry|last2=Van Exan|first2=Jessica|last3=Mills|first3=Jennifer S.|last4=Sockalingam|first4=Sanjeev|last5=Keating|first5=Leah|last6=Taube-Schiff|first6=Marlene|title=Binge eating in bariatric surgery candidates: The role of insecure attachment and emotion regulation|journal=Appetite|date=August 2015|volume=91|pages=69–75|doi=10.1016/j.appet.2015.03.026|pmid=25828596}}</ref> The disordered eating in insecure attachment does seem to have implications for overall health as well, with one study demonstrating a relationship with higher body mass index<ref name="wilkinson2010" /> and another demonstrating a higher risk for metabolic syndrome at mid life.<ref name="davis2014">{{cite journal|last1=Davis|first1=Cynthia R.|last2=Usher|first2=Nicole|last3=Dearing|first3=Eric|last4=Barkai|first4=Ayelet R.|last5=Crowell-Doom|first5=Cynthia|last6=Neupert|first6=Shevaun D.|last7=Mantzoros|first7=Christos S.|last8=Crowell|first8=Judith A.|title=Attachment and the Metabolic Syndrome in Midlife|journal=Psychosomatic Medicine|date=October 2014|volume=76|issue=8|pages=611–621|doi=10.1097/PSY.0000000000000107|pmid=25264975|pmc=5483991}}</ref>
'''Drug Use''' Recreational substances provide a powerful external means of regulating affect. Insecure attachment is considered to be one of the chief psychological constructs associated with increased risk for drug use.<ref name="kassel2007">{{cite journal|last1=Kassel|first1=JD|last2=Wardle|first2=M|last3=Roberts|first3=JE|title=Adult attachment security and college student substance use|journal=Addictive Behaviors|date=June 2007|volume=32|issue=6|pages=1164–76|pmid=16996225|doi=10.1016/j.addbeh.2006.08.005}}</ref><ref name="olsson2013">{{cite journal|last1=Olsson|first1=Craig A.|last2=Moyzis|first2=Robert K.|last3=Williamson|first3=Elizabeth|last4=Ellis|first4=Justine A.|last5=Parkinson-Bates|first5=Mandy|last6=Patton|first6=George C.|last7=Dwyer|first7=Terry|last8=Romaniuk|first8=Helena|last9=Moore|first9=Elya E.|title=Gene-environment interaction in problematic substance use: interaction between and insecure attachments|journal=Addiction Biology|date=2013|volume=18|issue=4|pages=717–726|doi=10.1111/j.1369-1600.2011.00413.x|pmid=22126256}}</ref><ref name="zeinali2011">{{cite journal|last1=Zeinali|first1=A|last2=Sharifi|first2=H|last3=Enayati|first3=M|last4=Asgari|first4=P|last5=Pasha|first5=G|title=The mediational pathway among parenting styles, attachment styles and self-regulation with addiction susceptibility of adolescents|journal=Journal of Research in Medical Sciences|date=2011|volume=16|issue=9|pages=1105–21|pmid=22973379|pmc=3430035}}</ref> A small study in Germany found that drug users were less likely to be secure than non-drug users and that heroine users in particular had a markedly high rate of fearful attachment.<ref name="schindler2009">{{cite journal|last1=Schindler|first1=Andreas|last2=Thomasius|first2=Rainer|last3=Petersen|first3=Kay|last4=Sack|first4=Peter-Michael|title=Heroin as an attachment substitute? Differences in attachment representations between opioid, ecstasy and cannabis abusers|journal=Attachment & Human Development|date=2009|volume=11|issue=3|pages=307–330|doi=10.1080/14616730902815009|pmid=19455456}}</ref> Researchers believed that these findings were in keeping with the “self-medication” hypothesis of drug use and that heroine, as opposed to other drugs of abuse, may target attachment distress more readily by acting more directly on the opioid system. [[Jaak Panksepp]] hypothesized in the 1980s that endogenous opioids are responsible for the warm, affiliative, interpersonal feelings that come with social connection, and this has been supported by recent evidence showing that naloxone administration, an opioid blocker, results in a decreased feeling of social connection in healthy individuals.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Inagaki|first1=Tristen K.|last2=Ray|first2=Lara A.|last3=Irwin|first3=Michael R.|last4=Way|first4=Baldwin M.|last5=Eisenberger|first5=Naomi I.|title=Opioids and social bonding: naltrexone reduces feelings of social connection|journal=Social Cognitive and Affective Neuroscience|date=2016|doi=10.1093/scan/nsw006|pmid=26796966|pmc=4847702|volume=11|issue=5|pages=728–735}}</ref> Recent work also demonstrates that attachment dimensions have bearing on natural opioid signaling, with brain scans showing that those high in attachment avoidance have decreased opioid receptor availability.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nummenmaa|first1=Lauri|last2=Manninen|first2=Sandra|last3=Tuominen|first3=Lauri|last4=Hirvonen|first4=Jussi|last5=Kalliokoski|first5=Kari K.|last6=Nuutila|first6=Pirjo|last7=Jääskeläinen|first7=Iiro P.|last8=Hari|first8=Riitta|last9=Dunbar|first9=Robin I.M.|last10=Sams|first10=Mikko|title=Adult attachment style is associated with cerebral μ-opioid receptor availability in humans|journal=Human Brain Mapping|date=2015|volume=36|issue=9|pages=3621–3628|doi=10.1002/hbm.22866|pmid=26046928}}</ref> In clinical samples insecure attachment is related to higher opioid use in chronic pain patients<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Andersen|first1=TE|title=Does attachment insecurity affect the outcomes of a multidisciplinary pain management program? The association between attachment insecurity, pain, disability, distress, and the use of opioids.|journal=Social Science & Medicine|date=May 2012|volume=74|issue=9|pages=1461–8|pmid=22398142|doi=10.1016/j.socscimed.2012.01.009}}</ref> and higher analgesic consumption during labor.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Costa-Martins|first1=JM|last2=Pereira|first2=M|last3=Martins|first3=H|last4=Moura-Ramos|first4=M|last5=Coelho|first5=R|last6=Tavares|first6=J|title=The role of maternal attachment in the experience of labor pain: a prospective study|journal=Psychosomatic Medicine|date=April 2014|volume=76|issue=3|pages=221–8|pmid=24608037|doi=10.1097/psy.0000000000000040|hdl=10316/47391}}</ref> In a study of young adult females, drug use was one of several risky behaviours that occurred more frequently in those with insecure attachment along with unsafe driving and sexual practices.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ahrens|first1=KR|last2=Ciechanowski|first2=P|last3=Katon|first3=W|title=Associations between adult attachment style and health risk behaviors in an adult female primary care population|journal=Journal of Psychosomatic Research|date=2012|volume=72|issue=5|pages=364–70|pmid=22469278|doi=10.1016/j.jpsychores.2012.02.002|pmc=3816981}}</ref>
'''Sex''' Risky sexual behaviour is defined as sexual contact with an increased risk of either unwanted pregnancy or sexually transmitted infection. In a study aimed at evaluating the evidence supporting six major risky sex theories, Leslie Simons and her colleagues found that only the social support and attachment theory had strong empirical support.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Simons|first1=Leslie Gordon|last2=Sutton|first2=Tara E.|last3=Simons|first3=Ronald L.|last4=Gibbons|first4=Frederick X.|last5=Murry|first5=Velma McBride|title=Mechanisms That Link Parenting Practices to Adolescents’ Risky Sexual Behavior: A Test of Six Competing Theories|journal=Journal of Youth and Adolescence|date=2015|volume=45|issue=2|pages=255–270|doi=10.1007/s10964-015-0409-7|pmid=26718543}}</ref> In the attachment theory model, risk is enhanced in insecurely attached individuals due to negative working models of relationships, reduced closeness in intimate relationships and through decreased self-control. In terms of conscious motivations for sex, attachment anxiety is related to many attachment-related motivations including using sex for desire for emotional closeness, reassurance, self-esteem enhancement, stress reduction, the experience and exertion of power, elicitation of caregiving from a partner, protection from a partner’s anger or bad moods.<ref name="davis2004">{{cite journal|last1=Davis|first1=Deborah|last2=Shaver|first2=Phillip R.|last3=Vernon|first3=Michael L.|title=Attachment Style and Subjective Motivations for Sex|journal=Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin|date=1 August 2004|volume=30|issue=8|pages=1076–1090|doi=10.1177/0146167204264794|pmid=15257790}}</ref> Those high in attachment avoidance report using sex for power or partner manipulation and endorse a desire to use sex as a way of avoiding emotional closeness.<ref name="davis2004" /> Accordingly, there is evidence that attachment avoidance is associated with positive attitudes towards casual sex, a higher number of casual sex partners, and an interest in emotionless sex and one-night stands.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Beaulieu-Pelletier|first1=Genevieve|last2=Philippe|first2=Frederick L.|last3=Lecours|first3=Serge|last4=Couture|first4=Stéphanie|title=The role of attachment avoidance in extradyadic sex|journal=Attachment & Human Development|date=2011|volume=13|issue=3|pages=293–313|doi=10.1080/14616734.2011.562419|pmid=21506032}}</ref>
'''Treatment adherence''' Attachment insecurity also plays an important role in how people follow the advice of the healthcare community. Attachment avoidance has consistently been linked to poorer treatment adherence<ref name="ciechanowski2004" /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Calia|first1=Rosaria|last2=Lai|first2=Carlo|last3=Aceto|first3=Paola|last4=Luciani|first4=Massimiliano|last5=Camardese|first5=Giovanni|last6=Lai|first6=Silvia|last7=Amato|first7=Giara|last8=Pietroni|first8=Valentina|last9=Salerno|first9=Maria Paola|last10=Pedroso|first10=Jose Alberto|last11=Romagnoli|first11=Jacopo|last12=Citterio|first12=Franco|title=Attachment style predict compliance, quality of life and renal function in adult patients after kidney transplant: preliminary results|journal=Renal Failure|date=2015|volume=37|issue=4|pages=678–680|doi=10.3109/0886022X.2015.1010989|pmid=25687387}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bennett|first1=JK|last2=Fuertes|first2=JN|last3=Keitel|first3=M|last4=Phillips|first4=R|title=The role of patient attachment and working alliance on patient adherence, satisfaction, and health-related quality of life in lupus treatment|journal=Patient Education and Counseling|date=2011|volume=85|issue=1|pages=53–9|pmid=20869188|doi=10.1016/j.pec.2010.08.005}}</ref> and more recently to no shows in scheduled follow up appointments.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sockalingam|first1=Sanjeev|last2=Cassin|first2=Stephanie|last3=Hawa|first3=Raed|last4=Khan|first4=Attia|last5=Wnuk|first5=Susan|last6=Jackson|first6=Timothy|last7=Okrainec|first7=Allan|title=Predictors of Post-bariatric Surgery Appointment Attendance: the Role of Relationship Style|journal=Obesity Surgery|date=2013|volume=23|issue=12|pages=2026–2032|doi=10.1007/s11695-013-1009-9|pmid=23757051}}</ref> Attachment avoidance has also been linked to lower rates of cervical cancer screening in both American and Iranian populations.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hill|first1=EM|last2=Gick|first2=ML|title=Attachment and barriers to cervical screening|journal=Journal of Health Psychology|date=2013|volume=18|issue=5|pages=648–57|pmid=22933580|doi=10.1177/1359105312454910}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Hajializadeh|first1=K|last2=Ahadi|first2=H|last3=Jomehri|first3=F|last4=Rahgozar|first4=M|title=Psychosocial predictors of barriers to cervical cancer screening among Iranian women: the role of attachment style and social demographic factors|journal=Journal of Preventive Medicine and Hygiene|date=2013|volume=54|issue=4|pages=218–22|pmid=24779284|pmc=4718322}}</ref>
===Healthcare utilization=== Attachment theory predicts that people high in attachment avoidance and people high in attachment anxiety would display different utilization of health care resources based on their prototypical behavioural responses when stressed.<ref name="maunder&hunter2015" /> The theory predicts that people high in attachment avoidance, when faced with an illness, are likely to minimize their symptoms, and wait longer to see a health care provider, since they view their own distress as a sign of unacceptable vulnerability and also because their internal working model dictates that other people are not useful in helping them manage distress. For those high in attachment anxiety, they would have higher distress when faced with an illness, less perceived ability to manage it on their own, and thus visit health care services more frequently to try to attain security. For those with high anxiety and high avoidance, or fearful attachment, they would be predicted to present less frequently than those with secure attachment, but show up in a crisis when they do, which may interfere with optimal care. Research findings have generally been supportive of these predictions. One of the earliest studies in the field found correlations between preoccupied attachment and increased symptom reporting and an inverse relationship between avoidant attachment and visits to health professionals.<ref name="feeney&ryan1994">{{cite journal|last2=Ryan|first2=SM|date=July 1994|title=Attachment style and affect regulation: relationships with health behavior and family experiences of illness in a student sample|journal=Health Psychology : Official Journal of the Division of Health Psychology, American Psychological Association|volume=13|issue=4|pages=334–45|pmid=7957012|last1=Feeney|first1=JA|doi=10.1037/0278-6133.13.4.334}}</ref> High attachment anxiety has been associated with increased symptom reporting and visits to healthcare providers,<ref name="ciechanowski2001">{{cite journal|last2=Katon|first2=WJ|last3=Russo|first3=JE|last4=Walker|first4=EA|date=January 2001|title=The patient-provider relationship: attachment theory and adherence to treatment in diabetes.|journal=The American Journal of Psychiatry|volume=158|issue=1|pages=29–35|pmid=11136630|last1=Ciechanowski|first1=PS|doi=10.1176/appi.ajp.158.1.29}}</ref> and high attachment avoidance associated with less visits and decreased treatment compliance<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Taylor|first1=RE|last2=Marshall|first2=T|last3=Mann|first3=A|last4=Goldberg|first4=DP|title=Insecure attachment and frequent attendance in primary care: a longitudinal cohort study of medically unexplained symptom presentations in ten UK general practices.|journal=Psychological Medicine|date=2012|volume=42|issue=4|pages=855–64|pmid=21880165|doi=10.1017/s0033291711001589}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sullivan|first1=M. D.|last2=Ciechanowski|first2=P. S.|last3=Russo|first3=J. E.|last4=Soine|first4=L. A.|last5=Jordan-Keith|first5=K.|last6=Ting|first6=H. H.|last7=Caldwell|first7=J. H.|title=Understanding Why Patients Delay Seeking Care for Acute Coronary Syndromes|journal=Circulation: Cardiovascular Quality and Outcomes|date=2009|volume=2|issue=3|pages=148–154|doi=10.1161/circoutcomes.108.825471|pmid=20031831}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brenk-Franz|first1=Katja|last2=Strauss|first2=Bernhard|last3=Tiesler|first3=Fabian|last4=Fleischhauer|first4=Christian|last5=Ciechanowski|first5=Paul|last6=Schneider|first6=Nico|last7=Gensichen|first7=Jochen|title=The Influence of Adult Attachment on Patient Self-Management in Primary Care - The Need for a Personalized Approach and Patient-Centred Care|journal=PLOS ONE|date=2015|volume=10|issue=9|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0136723|pages=e0136723|pmid=26381140|pmc=4575213|bibcode=2015PLoSO..1036723B}}</ref>

{{Taxobox | name = ''Betaretrovirus'' | virus_group = vi | ordo = '''''[[Ortervirales]]''''' | familia = ''[[Retroviridae]]'' | subfamilia = ''[[Orthoretrovirinae]]'' | genus = '''''Betaretrovirus''''' | type_species = ''[[Mouse mammary tumor virus]]'' | subdivision_ranks = Species | subdivision = ''[[Jaagsiekte sheep retrovirus]]''
''[[Langur virus]]''
''[[Mason-Pfizer monkey virus]]''
''[[Mouse mammary tumor virus]]''
''[[Squirrel monkey retrovirus]]'' }} '''''Betaretrovirus''''' is a [[genus]] of the [[Retroviridae]] [[family (biology)|family]]. It has [[type B retrovirus|type B]] or [[type D retrovirus|type D]] [[Morphology (biology)|morphology]]. The type B is common for a few exogenous, vertically transmitted and endogenous viruses of [[mouse|mice]]; some [[primate]] and [[sheep]] viruses are the type D. Examples are the [[mouse mammary tumour virus]], enzootic nasal tumour virus (ENTV-1, ENTV-2), and [[simian retrovirus]] types 1, 2 and 3 (SRV-1, SRV-2, SRV-3).{{cite journal |vauthors=Philipp-Staheli J, Marquardt T, Thouless ME, Bruce AG, Grant RF, Tsai CC, Rose TM | title = Genetic variability of the envelope gene of Type D simian retrovirus-2 (SRV-2) subtypes associated with SAIDS-related retroperitoneal fibromatosis in different macaque species | journal = Virol J | volume = 3 | pages = 11 | date = March 6, 2006 | pmid = 16515713 | doi = 10.1186/1743-422X-3-11 | pmc=1450265}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.expasy.org/viralzone/all_by_species/66.html '''Viralzone''': Betaretrovirus] {{Retroviruses}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q839040}} [[Category:Betaretroviruses]] {{Virus-stub}}

{{Infobox organization | name = Bio-1 | logo = BIO-1 web logo.jpg | founded_date = 2007 | location = {{flagicon|U.S.}} [[New Brunswick, New Jersey|New Brunswick]], [[New Jersey|NJ]] | area_served = [[Central New Jersey]] | key_people = '''Mary Ellen Clark'''
Executive Director
'''Lisa Weisser'''
Communications & Outreach Specialist | focus = [[Biology]], [[Biotechnology]] | method = Grants | homepage = [http://www.bio-1stop.org/ www.bio-1stop.org] }} '''Bio-1''' is a consortium of partners founded in 2007 designed to identify and promote bioscience in the [[Central New Jersey]] area. It is the result of a $5 million grant made available by the [[Workforce Innovation in Regional Economic Development]] (WIRED) program. ==Mission statement== Bio-1’s goal is to make Central New Jersey (CNJ) the next “hot spot” for the global bioscience industry, by creating high-quality, high-paying jobs and a skilled workforce. The five-county BIO-1 partnership is named for the Route 1 corridor from Rutgers to Princeton, around which most of CNJ’s biotech firms are clustered. The CNJ region, comprising [[Hunterdon]], [[Mercer County, New Jersey|Mercer]], [[Middlesex County, New Jersey|Middlesex]], [[Monmouth County, New Jersey|Monmouth]], and [[Somerset County, NJ|Somerset]] counties, has received $5 million, available under the Workforce Innovation in Regional Economic Development (WIRED) program from the [[United States Department of Labor]] (USDOL). The WIRED grant will be used to transform the rich array of existing bioscience education and training and economic development initiatives into an into a world class bioscience talent development system. The partnership has its roots in an initiative created by Governor [[Jon Corzine]] as part of his statewide economic strategy. This is the third WIRED investment in New Jersey, making it “the most WIRED state” in the U.S.[http://bio-one.org/about.html Growing and Developing Central New Jersey's Bioscience Workforce] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724101527/http://bio-one.org/about.html |date=July 24, 2008 }} 2007. ==Goals== In collaboration with representatives of all key players in the biosciences in CNJ, the Bio-1 initiative will focus on six key strategies: * Excite young people about the bio-sciences, especially focusing on underrepresented groups. * Create a consortium of biotechnology educators from the high school through university levels that will facilitate smooth career pathways through articulation agreements, mentoring and professional development. * Transform graduate education with the development of professional science master's degrees that integrate business and science, and interdisciplinary Ph.D. programs in biotech areas. * Increase bioscience workforce development with education and training opportunities. A “flak jackets to lab coats” initiative, for example, will focus on training and job placement in the bioscience industry for returning veterans. * Enhance linkages between education and industry through internships, cooperative education and mentoring. * Facilitate globally competitive “biobusinesses” by encouraging collaboration between business and education, supporting bioscience start-ups and leveraging existing global networks.[http://bio-one.org/about.html How will Bio-1 achieve its goal?] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080724101527/http://bio-one.org/about.html |date=July 24, 2008 }} 2007. ==Partners== ===Industry groups=== * [[BioNJ, Inc.]] (formerly Biotechnology Council of NJ, representing over 300 Member companies) * [http://www.hinj.org HealthCare Institute of New Jersey] (representing 34 pharmaceutical and medical device companies) ===Individual companies=== * [[Johnson & Johnson]] * [[Celgene]] * [[PTC Therapeutics]] * [[Elusys Therapeutics]] {{inline|date=March 2016}} The '''Bioindustry Park Silvano Fumero''' (BiPCa) is a [[Science park|Science and Technology Park]] located in [[Canavese]] near [[Turin]] in the north-west of [[Italy]]. The park was founded to promote and develop [[biotechnological]] research, to host companies operating [[research and development]], and pilot production in the [[life science]] sector. Companies such as [[Serono|Merck Serono]] and Bracco chose the Park as the location for their research and development activities.
==Services== The Park offers a complete set of support services to R&D activities, not only offering research facilities and scientific services, but also flexible and attractive financing solutions, sound project management and results evaluation.
The park is the owner of the '''Laboratory for Advanced Methodologies''' (LIMA) which performs exploitation of scientific results in the fields of [[Chemistry]], [[Molecular Biology]], [[Proteomics]] and [[Bioinformatics]]. LIMA, thanks to its solid co-operation with the [[University of Turin]] and CNR ISPA ([[Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche]]), is also a permanent training site for graduates and researchers.
A University Center in Imaging Technologies ('''CEIP''') managed by University of Torino is also active and is focused on the use of different technologies ([[MRI]], [[Ultrasound]], [[X-ray]], etc.) in order to evaluate new solutions in the diagnosis and assessment of the efficacy and efficiency of [[drug]]s.
==Start-ups== In 2005 BiPCa has launched, with the support of [[Regions of Italy|Regione]] [[Piemonte]], the '''Discovery''' initiative to identify and select innovative entrepreneurial ideas in the Biotech field. Eight start-ups have already been created from the beginning of the project in partnership with Eporgen venture, a [[Seed capital]] company focused on investment in new innovative entrepreneurial projects in the biotech field.
==Local cluster== Bioindustry Park is also acting as system integrator for the development of a [[Business cluster|local cluster]], bioPmed (http://www.biopmed.eu). Since 2009 Bioindustry Park acts as cluster management company for the development of the regional cluster bioPmed (www.biopmed.eu) on biotech and medtech. Created thanks to Regione Piemonte, it gathers more than 60 companies, research centres and three academic institutions (University of Turin, Università del Piemonte Orientale and [[Turin Polythecnic]]), who signed an agreement to create, build, support and animate the local cluster.
All the activities are carried out in cooperation with strong local actors, such as Turin Province and Turin Chamber of Commerce, CEIPiemonte, ALPS EEN and Patlib network and synergies with other local R&D initiatives are in place. The cluster is also founding member of the AlpsBioCluster (www.alpsbiocluster.eu) together with [[ Rhône-Alpes]] Region (France), Lombardy, South Tirol, Bavaria and Western Switzerland that intends to promote and foster transalpine competitiveness in the biotech and [[medical science]]s sectors.
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.bioindustrypark.eu}} *[http://www.biopmed.eu The bioPmed Life science Cluster]

{{unreferenced|date=July 2009}} '''Bisalog''', also ''Tagbis'', is a [[portmanteau]] of the words 'Bisaya' and 'Tagalog' which refers to either a [[Visayan languages|Visayan language]] or [[Tagalog language|Tagalog]] being infused with words or expressions from the other.
Speakers of Bisalog may often [[Code-switching|code-switch]] with [[Philippine English|English]], as well, resulting in what is sometimes called ''Bistaglish'' or ''Tagbislish''.
The word also used by radio station [[DZRH]] as a news/talk show where it brings the latest news from around the provinces (via [[Aksyon Radyo]]) every Sunday at 7am.
== Bisalog spoken == === Cebuan === * [[Central Visayas]] ** ''[[Cebu City]]'' * [[Northern Mindanao]] ** ''[[Cagayan de Oro]]'' * [[Davao Region]] ** ''[[Davaoeño language|Konyong Dabaw]]'' * [[Soccsksargen]] ** ''[[General Santos]]''
== Tagalog to Cebuano == * [[Metro Manila]] ({{small|from Visayan dynasty}}) * [[Laguna (province)|Laguna]] ({{small|sometimes}}) * [[Cavite]] ({{small|sometimes}}) * [[Rizal (province)|Rizal]] ({{small|sometimes}})
==See also== *[[Bisakol languages|Bisakol]] *[[Bislish]]
==External links== *[http://salitablog.blogspot.com/2005/01/filipino-vs-tagalog-debate-bisalog.html On Bisalog as spoken in Davao]

The '''Chanchlani Global Health Research Award''' is a Canadian health sciences award that recognizes a world leading scholar in the area of Global Health. Each year a discipline within Global Health (i.e. Determinants of Health, Policy Development, and Innovative Solutions) is chosen by the internal review committee at [[McMaster University]]. The review committee then selects the leading researcher based on interview and impact in the field. The award recipient receives a monetary prize of $25,000 and opportunity to present their research findings to researchers and students.
The award provides opportunities for informal scientific exchanges between the scientist/scholar and faculty, postdoctoral fellows, graduate and undergraduate medical students. The award was created by the [[Vasu Chanchlani|Chanchlani Family]] through $1 Million endowment along with a $250,000 donation at the [[McMaster University]] in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=CHANCHLANI GLOBAL HEALTH RESEARCH AWARD|url=http://fhs.mcmaster.ca/pgp/chanchlani_global_health_research_award.html|publisher=McMaster University}}</ref>
== Award recipients == Source: [https://fhs.mcmaster.ca/pgp/chanchlani_global_health_research_award.html McMaster University] *2017: Dr. John Ioannidis, ''Improving Research Practices: A Global Challenge'' *2016: Dr. [[Vikram Patel]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fhs.mcmaster.ca/pgp/chanchlani_global_health_research_award.html| title=Chanchlani Global Health Research Award|publisher=McMaster University|accessdate=7 November 2016}}</ref> ''The Black Dog: Why We Don’t Care''
*2015: Professor Dr. [[Ab Osterhaus]],<ref>http://fhs.mcmaster.ca/pgp/chanchlani_global_health_research_award.html</ref> Head of the Department of Virology of the Erasmus MC Rotterdam
*2014: Dr. [[Hans Rosling]], PhD, MD,<ref>{{cite web|url = http://fhs.mcmaster.ca/pgp/chanchlani_global_health_research_award.html|title= Chanchlani Global Health Research Award|publisher= McMaster University|accessdate = 9 December 2014}}</ref> Professor of International Health, Karolinska Institute
*2012: Dr. [[Madhukar Pai]] MD, PhD,<ref>{{cite news|title=Dr. Madhukar Pai and Dr. Nitika Pai co-laureates of the 2012 Chanchlani Global Health Research Award|url=http://publications.mcgill.ca/medenews/2012/10/01/dr-madhukar-pai-and-dr-nitika-pai-co-laureates-of-the-2012-chanchlani-global-health-research-award/|newspaper=McGill University Med e-News}}</ref> Associate Professor of Epidemiology, McGill University, ''The freakonomics of TB control in India'' and Dr. Nikika Pant Pai, MD, MPH, PhD,<ref>{{cite web|title=Dr. Madhukar Pai and Dr. Nitika Pai co-laureates of the 2012 Chanchlani Global Health Research Award|url=http://www.nitikapantpai.com/dr-madhukar-pai-and-dr-nitika-pai-co-laureates-of-the-2012-chanchlani-global-health-research-award/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130630005248/http://www.nitikapantpai.com/dr-madhukar-pai-and-dr-nitika-pai-co-laureates-of-the-2012-chanchlani-global-health-research-award/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2013-06-30}}</ref> Associate Professor of Medicine, McGill University, ''Point-of-care tests for HIV: innovation, synergy and impact'' (joint awards)
